intro: Ardinghelia, commonly known as the white fir, is a coniferous evergreen tree native to the mountainous regions of the western United States and parts of Canada. It belongs to the Pinaceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender trunk and dense, pyramidal crown. The tree has needle-like leaves that are dark green and arranged in spirals along the branches. Its cones are typically reddish-brown and contain winged seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Ardinghelia is valued for its timber and is also an important species in high-altitude ecosystems.
